ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Device physics of photovoltaics, statistics of charge carriers in and out of equilibrium, design of solar cells, and optical, electrical, and structural properties of semiconductors relevant to photovoltaics. We also discussed understanding both the applications and limitations of photovoltaic technology.
This course gave a comprehensive overview of the science behind photovoltaics, from the ground up. Lots of semiconductor physics, atomis physics, some circuits and atmospheric science too.
An intermediate insight into the design and working of photovoltaic devices.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was really high quality, the only weakness was that it went very fast! But as a result of that, we were able to cover a ton of material, more than your average STEM class.

The course is very multi-faceted. You learn about the theory, the experimental observation, and the state-of-the-art literature on how solar cells work. I think the course makes clear the limits of where we go in terms of theory, but sometimes even that can feel a bit challenging to gauge just how deep you know the material.
Not very well organized but very interesting material

Strengths: class was laid back. A lot of the assignments had extra credit questions that helped out with our grades quit a bit.
Weaknesses: homeworks were very tedious and confusing and not really related to the stuff covered in class sometimes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to someone really interested in renewable energy, with a decent physics background.  A lot of the physics is reintroduced as it is needed so you don't need to be a semiconductor expert, but some context helps.
Yeah, solar power is pretty cool and I thought learning about it was a good experience.
Yes, I was actually surprised at how few people take the class. I enjoy it and believe all majors will benefit from it.
Not really. Course was actually not very interesting. It was very tedious at times. There are better EE electives.

Yes! A great introduction to valuable concepts. I loved the way the course was structured, placing emphasis on getting exposure to ideas and equations in class that were quite complex, but there wasnt pressure to memorize these or use them in a test. Learning was the priority, rather than stressing over grades. Psets are super reasonable, and useful - using real world data for solar cells put things in context and helped cement the concepts we learnt in class.
